definition: spleen and stomach (digestive organs in TCM)/preferences/one's taste (e.g. in literature)
to penetrate deeply into the heart (idiom)/to gladden the heart/to refresh the mind
lit. doesn't hurt the spleen or the stomach/fig. something that is not critical

sentences.english: Although solitary accessory spleen is not uncommon, multiple accessory spleens are rare.
sentences.chinese: 虽然单一性副脾并非不常见，但多发性副脾仍属少见。

sentences.english: Microscopically, the splenic capsule appeared intact and there was no evidence of subcapsular hematoma formation.
sentences.chinese: 镜检脾包膜完整，无包膜下血肿形成。

sentences.english: Splenic embolization in treatment of hypersplenism using both silk threads and gelfoam.

sentences.english: Objective To evaluate the feasibility of percutaneous transsplenic portal indwelling catheterization.

sentences.english: The tumors and spleens were examined for pathologic change.

sentences.english: Shrinkage of the spleen and absorption of ascites were observed after operation.

sentences.english: Echocardiography found vegetations in 6 cases, spleen abscess in 1 case.

sentences.english: Confluenced immune spleen cells were inoculated in 12 plates with 96 wells each.

sentences.english: Objective To investigate the therapeutic methods of preserving spleens for splenic injuries.
sentences.chinese: 目的探讨外伤性脾破裂保脾方法的选择。

sentences.english: Most patients can have a laparoscopic splenectomy.
sentences.chinese: 大多数患者可实施腹腔镜脾切除术。

definition: spleen and stomach (digestive organs in TCM)/preferences/one's taste (e.g. in literature)
five viscera of TCM, namely: heart 心[xin1], liver 肝[gan1], spleen 脾[pi2], lungs 肺[fei4] and kidneys 腎|肾[shen4]

(TCM) six bowels (hollow organs), namely: gall bladder 膽|胆[dan3], stomach 胃[wei4], large intestine 大腸|大肠[da4 chang2], small intestine 小腸|小肠[xiao3 chang2], triple heater 三焦[san1 jiao1], bladder 膀胱[pang2 guang1]
(TCM) the three truncal cavities (thoracic, abdominal and pelvic), known as the "triple heater" or "San Jiao"
bodily fluids (general term in Chinese medicine)
qi and blood (two basic bodily fluids of Chinese medicine)
(TCM) consumptive disease, chronic deficiency disorder due to impaired function of inner organs, deficiency of qi, blood, yin and yang/asthenia
